sources.data_found: Center for Research Computing and Data: The center's main high-performance computing cluster, Metis, is a hybrid CPU/GPU cluster with a peak computing performance of more than 400 teraflops.

The success of CRCD in attracting external funds allowed the Center to obtain NIU's financing for the new Metis HPC system (commissioned in September of 2023), a hybrid CPU/GPU cluster equipped with a fast 1PB parallel storage system.
Facilities High Performance Computing Facilities Northern Illinois University has a high performance computing cluster named Gaea. It is a hybrid CPU/GPU cluster.
The hybrid GPU/CPU supercomputer has a capacity of more than 30 teraflops, meaning it can do more than 30 trillion calculations per second.
In 2023, 142 degrees were awarded to men at Northern Illinois University in Computer Science, which is 5.07 times more than the 28 female recipients with that same degree.
During the 2021-2022 academic year, Northern Illinois University handed out 132 bachelor's degrees in computer science. In 2022, 42 students received their master's degree in compsci from NIU.

student_data.notes: Undergraduate CS count estimated from 132 CS bachelor's degrees awarded in 2021-2022 (per CollegeFactual) × 4 years = 528 students. Graduate CS count of 120 from Peterson's data. PhD count not found separately from master's students.

gpu_resources.notes: NIU operates two HPC clusters: Metis (commissioned Sept 2023, 400+ teraflops) and Gaea (older system, 30+ teraflops). Both are described as hybrid CPU/GPU clusters but specific GPU models and counts are not publicly disclosed. Unable to find detailed hardware specifications.

analysis_notes: Data collected via multi-query approach. GPU specifications not publicly available despite multiple searches. Student counts estimated from degree completion data.
